LGTM, thanks!... But before merging, maybe we should quickly explain to francesperry@ the issue tomorrow and see if she's on board with this plan. (One thing I wonder is how the NoOp will show up in the Dataflow UI.)

We can't and shouldn't derive serializers. There's no registry for serializers like there is CoderRegistry for coders, and also the wire format of Kafka messages should be specified explicit rather than inferred implicitly.

I didn't mean 'deriving' serializers. Since user might provide coders anyway, KafkaIO could use `CoderBasedKafkaDeserializer`. I assumed `withKeyCoder()` and `withValueCoder()` methods will be removed in PR (or at least deprecated). Looks like those two are still required.

Run Flink ValidatesRunner

I rebuilt the code.
I don't have a good way to garbage collect. Maintain ids in memory and garbage collect ids by size and time.
I think we can use MapState and Timer of ProcessFunction when Flink 1.3 release.  Group by hashCode(value.getId()) % NUM_RESHARD_KEYS to use a finite set of keys to reduce key space, just like `DataflowRunner.Deduplicate`.
Thanks!  And ok, I see.

@jkff got it for CI. Maybe https://beam.apache.org/contribute/contribution-guide/ could be updated? In particular, `We recommend enabling Travis-CI continuous integration coverage on your private fork in order to easily test your changes before proposing a pull request. Go to Travis-CI, log in with your GitHub account, and enable coverage for your repository.` is a bit misleading.

Thanks for your review Thomas!
I first thought (see in PR header) that this null pointer exception could been due to the `Aggregator` being created and not written to but I managed to reproduce the null pointer exception with a simple pipeline with an `Aggregator` and a `State` (see unit test). You can see the null pointer exception if you comment line 386 (`if (steps != null)`) of `DirectRunner.java` and run `testAggregatorNotPresentInGraph` test

There is still the problem of the failing test if there's only a source. Have you looked into how hard it is to generate a dummy operator after the source if we only have a source?

rebased on master.
PTAL
R: @davorbonaci
You'll also need to rebase yet again. You might as well squash into fewer commits. Maybe just one, given the situation, but maybe there are a couple that make sense.

Checked offline and I am happy. Noting for posterity that the extremely high line count is spurious. Please resolve conflicts and run ValidatesRunner suites and then I'll be about ready to merge.

This blocks stable release, so we need to get in the large scale migration then iterate on the API details. We already needed to do this - this PR does not create more blocking work, but just blocks work we already needed to do.
R: @davorbonaci

OK I added the usage info.

Other question:
Did I miss any steps to make the CI checks succeed?
If they fail for most/all PRs, shouldn't we probably disable or fix them first?
I add checkGenerateDummyOperator method in `FlinkStreamingPipelineTranslator`.

I tried to have the simplest test pipeline as possible to reproduce the bug. And I started to have the null pointer exception in direct runner when I added the `State` to the test pipeline. @kennknowles maybe, as it might be `State` related, you would like to know about it.

This is due to how we collect all of the Aggregators from the pipeline - any replacement of any `ParDo` with any transform that isn't replaced by a `ParDo.MultiOutput`will not have aggregators picked up for it. Given that we're trying to remove Aggregators quite soon, I don't hugely think it's worth updating to work with Pipeline Surgery.

LGTM.

Travis tests are being currently removed. Although Travis tests give valid signals for Python development they are taking too long and timing out for Java tests. Part of the reason they are still there is Python on Mac tests are useful. (@jasonkuster may have more details)

Jenkins tests should not fail. If they do for an unrelated reason (like in this case) please file an issue for a flaky/failing tests.

Huh, @rangadi I guess we could make a serializer-based Coder - i.e. reuse the serializer (which the user has to provide) to also encode/decode values for Beam. And then indeed we could remove withKeyCoder and withValueCoder methods, and the whole CoderRegistry machinery. @peay WDYT?

One caveat is, to simulate a Coder, you need both a Serializer and a Deserializer, and it might be awkward to specify a Serializer on a KafkaIO.read() or a Deserializer on KafkaIO.write()...

> reuse the serializer (which the user has to provide) to also encode/decode values for Beam. 

User does not have to provide serializer for a reader (just needs deserializer). I think it is better for KafkaIO to follow recommended practice to handle Coders.

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11150234/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11150234)

Changes Unknown when pulling **29e054a8d7ffe6a061dbbe9a1885185b02f4e8ec on master** into ** on DSL_SQL**.

> User does not have to provide serializer for a reader (just needs deserializer). I think it is better for KafkaIO to follow recommended practice to handle Coders.

I thought Beam would derive the coders from type parameters. In fact runners could do this at the transform level rather than individual transforms.

The current PR implements inference of coders from type parameters of the Serializer/Deserializer. Due to Java's type erasure, Beam itself can't always do it automatically - otherwise users would never need to set coders anywhere (which, granted, would be great).

I'm afraid that only works for the one simple test case. What happens if there are two sources without any other operators? I think we'll then get the same exception.

I think we need to use the Pipeline surgery API to find out which sources don't have any successor operations and then create dummy operations for those.
Merging in progress (with @dhalperi).

```
git fetch --all
git checkout apache/DSL_SQL
git merge --no-ff -m "This closes #2584" github/pr/2584
git push apache HEAD:DSL_SQL
```
